definition: to come to accept an unpleasant fact/to get over sth/to cheer up
to look after/to take care of/to watch/to guard
to see/to look at/to read/to watch/to visit/to call on/to consider/to regard as/to look after/to treat (an illness)/to depend on/to feel (that)/(after verb) to give it a try/Watch out! (for a danger)

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: Take it easy, there are as many morons in China as in the US of A.
sentences.chinese: 看開點兒，中國跟美國情況一樣，也有很多傻瓜。

sentences.english: This is a non-event and China will get over it.
sentences.chinese: 在這個不算事件的問題上，中國將會看開的。

definition: to release (tension)/relief (from suspense)/to dispel (usu. with negative, unable to forget)
to let nature take its course (idiom)
in any case/no matter what
relieved/at ease/feel relieved
unimportant/not serious/it doesn't matter/never mind/it looks all right, but
to sever all relations with sb/determined/decisive
hard to say/unpleasant to say/can't be sure
to grieve/to be broken-hearted/to feel deeply hurt
impotent (idiom)/powerless/helpless
in the end/after all is said and done
to suffer losses/to come to grief/to lose out/to get the worst of it/to be at a disadvantage/unfortunately
to insist on/to demand/to impose
lit. that person/fig. the person you have been looking for/Mr Right/the girl of one's dreams
to resume/to restart/to start afresh
